content.rendered:
The top Ten (10) UK Universities in the League tables have been made available online. Is another university winning the gold medal, or have Oxford and Cambridge regained their monopoly at the top of the table? And last but not least, is your college one of the best in the nation?

Contents on This Page

Toggle
    • What Criteria is the University League Table Ranked?
  • 2024’s Top UK Universities
    • 1. University of Oxford
    • 2. University of Cambridge
    • 3. London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE)
    • 4. University of St Andrews
    • 5. Imperial College London
    • 6. Durham University
    • 7. Loughborough University

    • 10. University of Warwick

        • What is the top 1% university in the world?
        • Do university rankings matter UK?
        • Is it hard to get to University of Oxford?
        • What GPA do you need to get in Oxford?

In the League tables ranking, 130 UK Universities are published annually by the Complete University Guide (CUG). This incorporates 74 subject tables and an extra positioning of 13 Expressions, Show, and Music schools and centers.

What Criteria is the University League Table Ranked?

It considers the entirety of the accompanying factors:

  • Entry Requirements
  • Student Satisfaction
  • Research Quality
  • Research Intensity
  • Graduate Prospects (Outcomes),
  • Graduate Prospects (On Track),
  • Student-Staff Ratio
  • Academic Services Spend
  • Facilities Spend
  • Degree Completion

2024’s Top UK Universities

Based on the criteria given in the order a University league table is ranked, the following Universities top in the list.

Read Also>>>Which UK Universities Have the Easiest Admissions Procedures?

1. University of Oxford

The University of Oxford is widely considered to be the oldest institution in the English-speaking world, though the precise date of its establishment is unknown. In fact, teaching has been documented since 1096.

The Oxford alumni list reads like a “who’s who” of famous people from around the world, as you might expect. Stephen Hawking, J.R.R. Tolkien, Malala Yousafzai, and numerous others are included in this. Oxford finally overtook Cambridge for the top spot last year, and it has remained here in the 2024 league table. However, admission to Oxford does not guarantee a top-notch degree. When one student tried to sue the university for £1 million because he didn’t get a first, he discovered this for himself.

2. University of Cambridge

The University of Cambridge is the second-oldest university in the UK, established in 1209. As you probably already know, Cambridge has a lot of famous alumni, like Stephen Fry, David Mitchell, Richard Ayoade, Thandiwe Newton, and others.

Cambridge consistently ranks among the top two UK universities in league tables. It dropped from first to second place last year, but it had been first for ten years in a row before.

It’s hard to argue that the top spot wasn’t well-deserved given that they’ve already hired a Professor of Lego!

Also, don’t be put off by Cambridge’s prestigious reputation. Take inspiration from our interview with YouTuber Ibz Mo, who broke boundaries at Cambridge, if you’re not sure if it’s for you.

3. London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE)

In CUG’s UK university rankings, the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) has never fallen outside the top five. And this year, it’s third, taking London’s top spot.

The list of famous university alums is also pretty impressive. It has hosted people like Sir David Attenborough and Mick Jagger. Additionally, former Prime Minister Clement Attlee taught there.

4. University of St Andrews

The oldest university in Scotland is St. Andrews, founded in 1413.

You may be aware that Prince William and Kate Middleton, who met while attending the school, are among the St. Andrew’s alumni.

Every year, the university is ranked among the best in the nation. Notwithstanding, it truly appears to succeed in Understudy Fulfillment – St Andrews is top in the UK with a score of 85%.

5. Imperial College London

Originally a part of the University of London, Imperial College London gained its independence in 2007. With a focus on science, engineering, business, and medicine, Imperial has ranked among the top five universities in the UK for the past seven years.

The author H.G. Wells and Queen guitarist Brian May, who studied astrophysics at the university, are among its alumni. The university has approximately 18,000 students.

Imperial’s Graduate Prospects rank second in the United Kingdom with a score of 92 percent. In this way, your possibilities getting a new line of work when you graduate are surprisingly better than at Oxford or Cambridge!

6. Durham University

After Oxford and Cambridge, Durham University was the first university to open in England in over 600 years when it was established in 1832. It consistently ranks among the UK’s best universities and has one of the highest proportions of students with private educations.

Additionally, Durham is home to a number of notable former students. Ed Gamble and Nish Kumar, comedians, and former Bond actor Roger Moore round out the list.

According to CUG, Durham has excellent scores for Graduate Prospects and Degree Completion. Be that as it may, it tumbles down somewhat on its Understudy Fulfillment rating.

7. Loughborough University

For the seventh year running, Loughborough University ranks in the top 10 in the United Kingdom.

The university, which is best known for its love of athletics and served as Team GB’s headquarters during the London Olympics, ranks highly in part due to its excellent engineering and art and design departments.

Loughborough puts a great deal of accentuation on understudies graduating with an inside and out range of abilities. As a result, it gives all undergraduate students the chance to earn a degree by working for a year in industry.

8. University of Bath

Soundness is the situation at the College of Shower. For the fourth year in a row, it is currently ranked in the top 10.

The university ranks among the top 10 overall in terms of graduate prospects. Naturally, Bath, a stunning World Heritage Site, serves as its headquarters.

It’s important to note that a slew of successful athletes, including a slew of Olympic medalists, studied at Bath, even though many of the school’s graduates may not be familiar to you.

9. University College London (UCL)

University College London (UCL) always has a good chance of making the top 10 in the UK. It ranks highly in the league table’s more academic categories, like Research Quality and Entry Standards.

However, UCL has a long history of leading the way. It was the first university to accept students of any race, social class, or religion and to treat women and men equally.

Jonathan Ross, Chris Martin of Coldplay, and Alexander Graham Bell, the telephone’s inventor, are just a few of its notable alumni.

10. University of Warwick

Warwick excels in the majority of areas, which is not surprising for a university of this caliber. However, it ranks highly for Graduate Prospects and Research Quality.

Warwick, like all of the universities on this list, has welcomed a lot of well-known people over the years. Some of its notable alumni include Frank Skinner, Ruth Jones, and Stephen Merchant.

FAQ

What is the top 1% university in the world?
The University of Oxford tops the ranking for the seventh consecutive year.
Do university rankings matter UK?

All in all, whether students are starting to pick where to concentrate on in the UK or change an ongoing decision, College rankings can assume a critical part in an understudies direction.

Is it hard to get to University of Oxford?

Though the average Oxford acceptance rate is 13.5%, this rate decreases significantly for its most competitive courses, which have a greater number of applications
Read Also on Which UK Universities Have the Easiest Admissions Procedures?

What GPA do you need to get in Oxford?

3.7 out of 4.0, Undergraduate qualifications: If your graduate course at Oxford requires a ‘first class undergraduate degree with honours’ in the UK system, you will usually need an overall GPA of at least 3.7 out of 4.0 or 4.5 out of 5.0.
